Collaborative Research: Relative Abundance and Diversity of Antibiotic Resistance Genes and Pathogens in Reclaimed Versus Potable Water Distribution Systems

Water sustainability, antibiotic resistance, and opportunistic pathogens represent three critical global health challenges. Expanding the use of reclaimed water is critical to advancing water sustainability. However, important knowledge gaps remain with respect to microbial risk and public health. Research results will directly benefit the water utilities and water stressed regions participating in this project by vetting existing practices and revealing new and effective management strategies that proactively address public health concerns. Results will be disseminated via peer reviewed literature, presentations at conferences attended by water professionals, and through the newsletter and other avenues sponsored by the Water Resources Research Center at U. Arizona. The project will also support Native American and other underrepresented undergraduate researchers at U. Arizona and two graduate students at Virginia Tech, who will be trained across disciplines through the Interfaces of Global Change Interdisciplinary Graduate Education Program. Additional undergraduate researchers will participate through the NSF Interdisciplinary Water Science and Engineering REU site and other NSF REU sites at Virginia Tech. The project will be an excellent training platform at the nexus of public health and sustainability, with training opportunities in the emerging field of metagenomics.

The proposed research is the first comprehensive assessment of reclaimed water distribution systems microbiome, providing insight into the occurrence and regrowth of microbial constituents of emerging concern in reclaimed water. The interplay between physico-chemistry and microbial ecology in reclaimed water distribution systems will be revealed using an integrated lab and field sampling plan that includes high throughput amplicon sequencing, metagenomics, and quantitative PCR along with traditional culturing and chemical approaches that have been well established for potable water distribution systems. The approach will identify key factors, such as: level of assimilable organic carbon, presence of disinfectant, type of disinfectant, water age, and temperature that influence microbial constituents of emerging concern in reclaimed water distribution systems and thus inform future management guidelines. It has only recently been established that microbial regrowth in reclaimed water distribution systems is the primary source of waterborne disease in developed countries; however, regrowth in reclaimed water distribution systems is relatively uncharacterized, despite reasonable expectations and preliminary results that suggest even greater potential for problems due to higher levels of nutrients, source water containing microbial constituents of emerging concern, and nuances of reclaimed water distribution systems operation in water stressed regions. Left unaddressed, these concerns will impede the direct use of reclaimed water and call into question existing reclaimed water distribution systems practices. The proposed effort will address key knowledge gaps and support rationally engineered water reuse systems that allow the benefits of reclaimed water to be fully realized, while protecting public health. The proposed work will achieve the following Objectives: O1: Conduct a lab study to examine the interplay between water treatment, nutrient level, disinfectant type, distribution system design/operation, and temperature in selecting for microbial regrowth and microbial constituents of emerging concern occurrence in reclaimed water distribution systems; O2: Conduct a field survey comparing the microbiome composition and microbial constituents of emerging concern occurrence of paired reclaimed water distribution systems and potable water distribution systems as a function of kind of treatment, nutrient levels, secondary disinfectant type and dose, distribution system materials, and water age; and, O3: Based on  O1 and O2, identify engineering practices that are promising for minimizing the occurrence of microbial constituents of emerging concern in reclaimed water distribution systems to inform future design, management, and standards for safe application of reclaimed water for non-potable and potable reuse.

por.por_cntn:
Antibiotic resistance is a major challenge to human health. However, it is not known to what extent the water cycle, including the use of recycled water, may cause amplification or attenuation of antibiotic resistance.  Antibiotic resistance genes are pieces of DNA that allow bacteria to survive antibiotic therapies and have been targeted in several scientific studies as an indicator of the presence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.  Direct detection of these genes, though, does not indicate that they are present in pathogenic (disease-causing) bacteria or that they are present in living bacterial cells.

This sub-project supported a larger research project, “Relative Abundance and Diversity of Antibiotic Resistance Genes and Pathogens in Reclaimed vs. Potable Water Systems.” The larger project used cutting-edge molecular methods to gain a fundamental understanding of the dissemination of antibiotic resistance genes in recycled water, while the sub-project focused on assessing risk to humans by culturing microorganisms of interest (E. coli and Enterococcus) and assessing their resistance to widely-used antibiotics. In this way, we addressed the question of viability and antibiotic resistance expression of microbiological contaminants in recycled and potable water systems.

Four cooperating utilities (two in Arizona, one in California, one in Florida) performed collections of water from their recycled and potable distribution systems. These were performed four times over the length of the project from each utility.

The culture-based results were a testament to the quality of recycled and potable water in the U.S. No culturable E. coli were found within the treated potable water systems, though trace numbers of E. coli were found in the raw (untreated) water. The finding of E. coli in untreated water was not surprising, given that some of the raw water samples originated in part from surface waters with potential contamination from wildlife. Enterococcus results for the potable system raw water of both municipalities mirror those of E. coli.

Reclaimed water samples showed a general trend of high E. coli and Enterococcus in raw wastewater, with very few detected in the distribution systems. Thus, the antibiotic resistance assessment resulting from this project is strongly dominated by isolates originating from untreated or partially treated source water. Resistance analyses were conducted in 96-well plates (Photo 1), with a single bacterium in each well exposed to the target antibiotic, followed by incubation and assessment of growth. E. coli were evaluated for resistance to erythromycin, cephalexin, and sulfamethoxazole; Enterococcus were evaluated for resistance to erythromycin, cephalexin, and vancomycin.

Resistance rates varied widely, but averages agreed with antibiotic resistance levels found in human gut bacteria and thus, no finding of elevated antibiotic resistance was found in the bacteria that had gone through water treatment. The number of isolates was too low for statistical comparison between potable and recycled water systems.

This sub-project provided training in laboratory methods (biosafety methods, bacterial culturing and enumeration, and assessment of antibiotic resistance) to two University of Arizona undergraduates. Following graduation in May 2017, Victoria Obergh entered medical school at Arizona Midwestern University. Emily Gudvangen graduated in May 2017 and will soon graduate with a Master’s Degree in Medical Biotechnology from the University of Arizona. Training these students in proper laboratory procedure certainly contributed to their confidence and success in the sciences.

Research results from the cultural resistance analyses from recycled and potable water systems were presented at multiple professional/scientific meetings over the length of the study, including the 2015 ASA-CSSA-SSSA International Annual Meetings (Minneapolis, MN), the Arizona Water 2016 Spring Research Symposium (Tempe, AZ), and the Arizona Registered Sanitarians’ Conference (November 3, 2016). In addition, this study was the subject of public meetings and newspaper stories in Arizona. The culture-based results form the basis of a publication that will be submitted for peer review in winter 2019.

The methods developed for this project will be integral to confirming the human health impacts of indicator bacteria found within recycled and potable water systems. Though molecular methods are crucial for accurately quantifying regrowth of bacteria, the ultimate question – whether the antibiotic resistance levels in bacteria can impact human health – can best be addressed through cultivation of living bacteria. Ultimately, the results of this culturing sub-project will be merged with the larger dataset to identify engineering practices that minimize microbial regrowth, and provide management guidelines for the safe application of recycled wastewater for potable and non-potable uses.
